awd_titl_txt: Receiving Contexts of Return through Deportation
awd_abstract_narration:
The research supported by this award addresses one facet of the global migration crisis: return migration through deportation. Deportation is a widely significant contemporary social, political, and intellectual problem. Existing social science scholarship has theorized deportation as a straightforward politics of exclusion that culminates in the removal of people from one national territory and their return to another. However, for most people, deportation is not only an endpoint; it also marks the beginning of long-term efforts to build viable post-deportation lives. Yet despite the key role that nation states play in shaping their citizens' decisions to migrate in the first place as well as their post-deportation experiences, contexts of return have received little sustained research attention. This project takes a broader perspective to provide the more complete picture that is needed by both theorists and policy makers.

The research will be carried out by Loyola University of Chicago anthropologist, Dr. Ruth M. Gomberg-Munoz.  Using a multi-year and multi-sited approach, this project involves the sustained ethnographic research necessary to better understand the sociopolitical afterlife of deportation and its effects in both Mexico and the United States. The research design comprises a three-year study of the contexts of deportees in Mexico City and Chicago. The researcher will use a mix of ethnographic research methods including participant observation, digital ethnography, in-depth and follow-up interviews, targeted semi-structured interviews, and research on state and municipal policies regarding migration and deportees. The study population will include Mexican government agents, a sample of deportees, and organizations that work with deportees. Findings from this research will advance a more robust and reliable theorization of life after deportation in three key ways. 1. The project's longitudinal design will provide the time depth needed to understand post-deportation life. 2. The analytical focus on deportees' interactions with Mexican state agencies will illuminate the role of emigrant states in shaping contexts of migrant return. 3. Attention to the quotidian activities of deportees will shed light on dynamic, cross-border cultural formations that arise in response to global securitization concerns. Using a collaborative approach to research design and dissemination, this project will make a timely and important intervention in social science scholarship on migration and removal, and it will contribute critical information for policy makers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

Our research found that, with an average US residence of more than 15 years, deportees experience long-term problems of family separation, joblessness, and homelessness in Mexico, despite their formal citizenship status. Our respondents additionally report a dearth of governmental support, including lack of assistance with job and housing placement, identity documentation, medical attention, and social integration upon return to Mexico. Significantly, we also found that deportees who are left to fend for themselves by the US and Mexican governments do just that by forming community networks through which they share information, resources, and support. These findings have significant implications for broader theorizations of citizenship, states, and social movements in the current period. Our research has so far generated three peer-reviewed publications, four commissioned essays in peer-reviewed outlets, a publicly accessible research report, and a book manuscript in-progress. 

 

Broader Impacts:

Our research led to the creation of a major digital project. Using our study data, our team identified eight major categories of need for migrants and deportees across the North American region: legal assistance, education, deportation defense, identity documentation, migration assistance, family reunification, emergency health, mental health, physical health, work, and housing.  The result is Solidarity Map, now run by trained members of the deported community in Mexico City. 

Four undergraduate students worked as research assistants on the project. These assistantships provide skill development in applied anthropological techniques such as rapid assessment, program evaluation, and asset mapping. The project also funded technological training and a year's salary for two community members to maintain the mapping project.
